If Congress wants to address rising food insecurity among children, it should extend P-EBT for the 2020-2021 school year. Failure to do so is the difference between millions of children having at least one meal a day or no meal at all.  

Read more here: https://bit.ly/Pandemic-EBT

Even before the pandemic, the U.S. had a food insecurity problem. But, the #COVID19 crisis caused food insecurity to spike to 23 percent in April. 

The situation is worse for Black families ‚Äì almost 40% of those with children suffer from a lack of food. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EfELGdJWoAEw2A4.png

Now, with thousands of districts announcing full or partial remote learning schedules for the 2020-2021 school year, it's critical that Congress extend P-EBT so children don‚Äôt go hungry.

Failure to do so would effectively be a dramatic cut to our nation‚Äôs school meals programs.

The P-EBT program included in the Families First Act was only authorized for the 2019-2020 school year because policymakers hoped #COVID19 would be contained before the fall.

That hasn‚Äôt worked out.

Congress created the Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) program to help those children during the #COVID19 crisis by providing their families with a debit card to help pay for the meals they missed. They received about $5.60 per child per day.
Millions of children living in poverty used to depend on the National School Lunch Program for one of their meals. It helped prevent them from going hungry. Then schools closed because of #COVID19.
